<div id="csl-bib-meta-J6UBK4NS" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-J6UBK4NS" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Christie examines the ideas presented by Jonathan Quong in his book "The Morality of Defensive Force." Quong suggests that people become morally liable to defensive harm when they treat others with less respect than they deserve. He also argues that whether someone is to blame (culpability) should not affect the morality of defensive actions. Christie disagrees with Quong's dismissal of culpability, arguing that Quong does not successfully prove his approach is better than considering culpability when determining liability to defensive harm. This debate matters because it influences how we think about self-defense and the ethical use of force in everyday situations.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-J6UBK4NS" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Defensive Force, Moral Liability, Self-Defense, Culpability, Respect
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-J6UBK4NS" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    What are the justifications and constraints on the use of force in self-defense? In his book The Morality of Defensive Force, Jonathan Quong presents the moral status account to address this and other fundamental questions. According to the moral status account, moral liability to defensive harm is triggered by treating others with less respect than they are due. At the same time, Quong rejects the relevance of culpability to the morality of defensive harming. In this article I argue that this rejection of culpability is unfounded and that Quong fails to establish his account as superior to the culpability account of liability to defensive harm.
  </article>
